ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In my first rotation I gained the ability to use optical tweezers and how to interpret the data obtained from this technique. In my second rotation I learned how to use NMR techniques for protein studies. I learned how a lab functions in both cases and how the interactions between the people in a lab work at a professional level.
I gained a great deal of hands-on experience and have a better understanding of the direction that my graduate career will take.

I developed foundational skills in several areas of biology, including working with nucleic acids, cloning, running gels, etc. I did not have these skills before rotations because my background was not in biology. I also learned the logic and limitations behind each of these techniques.
I learned various techniques as I rotated in the Klein and Pyle labs

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course value heavily depends on who the student chooses to rotate with. Overall it a very good course.
Rotations are great but very stressful!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Of course. This is a must for anyone attempting to work in a lab.
Rotations are required, but they are a great way to get acclimated to graduate work and the lab environment.
Yes, I would. The Xiong lab is a great lab to rotate it. All the lab members are very nice and inviting, and the research in interesting. I learned a lot from my rotation in this lab.
